message.subject: RE: Can we re-do this post?
message.body:
There is a way with some of the analytics tools; even bitly; to get some of the engagement metrics.   Please name some other content engagement analytics tools.   Jeremiah may have some as well
 
From: Jeff Henshaw <jeff.henshaw@envorso.com> 
Sent: Wednesday, February 1, 2023 8:34 AM
To: Amelia Forczak <amelia@pithywordsmithery.com>; Todd Warren <todd@envorso.com>
Cc: Candice Kriel <Candice@envorso.com>; Adrian Balfour <Adrian@envorso.com>; Scott Tobin <scott.tobin@envorso.com>
Subject: Re: Can we re-do this post?
 
Thanks for fielding the feedback, Amelia. I have no reservations about trusting the A/B data that shows more views when tricks like this are used. I spent a few years of my past life managing Bing’s search results page, optimizing for engagement <https://youtu.be/_dGAzDd18x4>  (this was a strategy that I started in 2010 and is still being built upon in Bing today), with days spent poring over mega-scale data. We developed techniques to not just track clicks, but to weight data based upon nature of engagement. 
 
What I’d like to see us do here is begin to understand the nature of engagement – positive or negative – that comes with the upticks. LinkedIn may not give us nuances like dwell-time or click-through status on each post (do they? Last I checked, not), but we should review each case for downstream impact.
 
Let me share an example from last night: @Todd Warren <mailto:todd@envorso.com> , the author of the blog post himself, re-shared Envorso’s post. That’s the dream scenario of engagement! It’s a duplication of one’s post to an entirely new community.  Here’s a screenshot of Todd’s repost: <https://www.linkedin.com/search/results/content/?fromMember=%5B%22ACoAAAAEBsABlN322VENnvstsIvzfiw5rqpFOkk%22%5D&heroEntityKey=urn%3Ali%3Afsd_profile%3AACoAAAAEBsABlN322VENnvstsIvzfiw5rqpFOkk&keywords=todd%20warren&position=0&searchId=502db7a2-cc1a-466c-858c-667661c581a9&sid=aF(&update=urn%3Ali%3Afs_updateV2%3A(urn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A7026230357574262785%2CBLENDED_SEARCH_FEED%2CEMPTY%2CDEFAULT%2Cfalse)> 
 

 
I felt sad for Todd and for his LinkedIn network when I encountered this in my feed, because it has no link to the blog post!  Here is the guy posting about his blog update and readers have no way to click through to read what Todd is posting about.  This makes Todd look forgetful, and Envorso look kind of unprofessional, IMO.
 
This would fall into the negative engagement. We got some extra view-count, but no engagement. 
 
There are many other techniques that can be employed to boost awareness, view counts, and positive engagement with us. Things like replacing stock photos with actual people’s photos, including brand new shiny vehicles in posts (our team has a huge set of photo from events), and asking our employee base to re-share high-value posts to their networks. I’d love to see us employ all of these techniques, which I’m sure is on your roadmap. I wouldn’t suggest doing things counter to A/B data in the future based upon arbitrary opinion, but I do feel pretty strongly that this example illustrates what we should not be doing given the negative impressions (more impressions, sure) it can cause during engagement.
 
In the meantime, @Todd <mailto:todd@envorso.com>  you might want to edit your post in include a link to what you’re talking about. 
 
Thanks,
Jeff

Subject: Re: Can we re-do this post?
 
Hi Jeff,
Thanks for your feedback. Have you seen Envorso's viewership stats on recent posts? Even though there are over 4K followers, posts are not getting seen. (Some posts get around 200 views, which is super low.) We are trying to do whatever we can to raise the view rate or people won't even have a chance to see the post and click through. I've A/B tested this strategy and it works better to get more views. If you guys want to do it differently in the future, that's up to you. The strategy that we use when we're starting from nothing is different from what we would do if we had much more momentum. 


Thanks,

On Tue, Jan 31, 2023 at 11:45 PM Jeff Henshaw <jeff.henshaw@envorso.com <mailto:jeff.henshaw@envorso.com> > wrote:
	I’m very surprised to see that guidance. The post may do slightly better by not off-site linking (though I will talk to the LI folks about exactly how much), but the readership drop that we’d get would more than negate any algorithm gain. 
	And this same algorithm summarizes the text post so the “link is in the comments” is hidden for 99.999% of users behind a “…” to read more.
	 
	Even Microsoft itself, LinkedIn’s owners, link to their own blog posts.  Example:  https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:7026337792884412416/ <https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fupdate%2Furn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A7026337792884412416%2F&data=05%7C01%7Cjeff.henshaw%40envorso.com%7Cc5e54ac9600d4e93283a08db0452e8c4%7Cd9c3cfd0bde448eb9b3a9c30c0d51745%7C0%7C0%7C638108526410105047%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=xKVA8gn0MZcDTdArBhtvztVdIoGy4ybFQCmR%2FgL%2FRAA%3D&reserved=0> 
	 
	Worst of all: anyone who re-shares the Envorso post, which we absolutely want people to do! – loses the comments on their re-post, orphaning their re-share and losing 100% of click-throughs. In fact, this is how I noticed it: I went to re-share Envorso’s post to my own followers, and found it had no link! So I deleted my re-share and started from scratch. <https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fupdate%2Furn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A7026345272423157760%2F&data=05%7C01%7Cjeff.henshaw%40envorso.com%7Cc5e54ac9600d4e93283a08db0452e8c4%7Cd9c3cfd0bde448eb9b3a9c30c0d51745%7C0%7C0%7C638108526410105047%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=OPrdpUQrmsN8qPc2XUr9UoLwICN1gLrIO4P0pVHtjuc%3D&reserved=0> 
	 
	Amelia, it’s probably reports like this that drive your guidance:  https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/how-leverage-linkedin-using-new-algorithm-lynnaire-johnston/ <https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fpulse%2Fhow-leverage-linkedin-using-new-algorithm-lynnaire-johnston%2F&data=05%7C01%7Cjeff.henshaw%40envorso.com%7Cc5e54ac9600d4e93283a08db0452e8c4%7Cd9c3cfd0bde448eb9b3a9c30c0d51745%7C0%7C0%7C638108526410105047%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=%2FaRjNqI5uWpxZm7AzweDYLt5Z4PfPXgc0S6uPGi5Mj8%3D&reserved=0> 
	However, the algo sort order is more than made up for be the interesting-ness of content. And if links get clicks, those click spike the algorithm that people find it interesting and will more than make up for external-link penalties.
	This comment-link method that we are using is called algorithm end-running, and it trades a small uptick in immediate-term impressions for a grand-canyon-sized loss of valuable engagement that interesting links provide people.
	 
	And TBH, it looks a little unprofessional to me, like “Oh we forgot to include the link so we’re adding it as a comment.”
	 
	I hope we’ll reconsider this.  Thanks a ton for listening to the feedback. Comes from a lot of years of building front-ends for properties like this.
	 
	Thanks,
	Jeff

	Subject: Can we re-do this post? 
	 
	This post doesn’t include a link to Bob’s actual blog post. It’s just a photo and a mention of it. Then then link is in the comments.  That is a big barrier to click-through.
	 
	Instead, I recommend putting the link in the post itself.  LinkedIn grabs the metadata and bundles the glam photo in automagically, like this. <https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fupdate%2Furn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A7026345272423157760%2F&data=05%7C01%7Cjeff.henshaw%40envorso.com%7Cc5e54ac9600d4e93283a08db0452e8c4%7Cd9c3cfd0bde448eb9b3a9c30c0d51745%7C0%7C0%7C638108526410105047%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=OPrdpUQrmsN8qPc2XUr9UoLwICN1gLrIO4P0pVHtjuc%3D&reserved=0>   In this example, people can click the photo or the headline to read the post itself.
	 
	Recommend re-posting that. It’s good content. Well done, Todd!
	 
	Jeff
